titleStmt.title: British Book Trade Index

publicationStmt.publisher: Published by the University of Victoria Humanities Computing and Media Centre, based on a publication by the Bodleian Libraries.

sourceDesc.p: The original source for this dataset is a database dump by the Bodleian Libraries at .

address.addrLine: 19 Old Compton St. Kilburn. 101 Berwick St, Soho. 47 Bell St, Paddington. 143 Leadenhall St &c

org.note: designer for Hull theatre Born Scarborough; died Masham, Yorks. Taken on embassy to China in 1788
insolvent debtor in Debtors' Prison for London & Middlesex 1847
Referred to 6/4/1699 in Selby Will of Mary I

address.addrLine: Smithfield nr the Queen's-Head Tavern. Nr Hosier La. King's Hd in the Old Bailey

org.note: Possibly successor to Charles Ibbotson. Possibly succeeded by Thomas Marsden. Possibly father of Abraham Ibbotson 1823b

address.addrLine: Green's House Mill [i.e., Greenhouse Mill]. Outseats (1846).

org.note: master paper maker. Possibly succeeded by Abraham Ibbotson at Green's House Mill in 1849. Freeholder in 1827

address.addrLine: Rivelin Paper Mills &c Warehses: Orchard St. Holly St

org.note: Father of Thomas Ibbotson of Green's Hse Paper Mill. Estate worth £25,000 at death
From Dore. Possibly the same as or related to Dennis Ibbotson
Son of Joseph, bro John, Henry & William Ibbotson. Tenant of J S Vesey. Paid excise duties at Sheffield Collection in 1816
Part Robert Ibbotson. Possibly the same as or related to Daniel Ibbotson

address.addrLine: [Rivelin Paper Mills]. Res: Stannington Upper Gate

org.note: Paper mill hand. Possibly mo Annie Ibbotson, paper-mill hand, aged 16 in 1881 (same address)
Mill tenant. Trading as Ibbotson & Co. Tenant of Duke of Norfolk Estates. Imprisoned for debt `Lond Gazette' 23/5/1820
Son of Joseph, bro Denis, John & William Ibbotson. Possibly sold interest in paper mill to Denis in 1801
Son of Joseph, bro Denis etc. Possibly sold interest in paper mill to Denis in 1801. Assoc S Brownell. Possibly the same as or related to J Ibbotson of Hayfield or White Hall Mill, Derbys
Mill owner. Master paper maker. Possibly the same as or related to John Ibbotson of Hathersage or White Hall Mill, Derbys. Paid excise duties at Manchester Collection in 1816

address.addrLine: 6 Cannon Ct,Cannon St(1816-22);Oldknows Wharf,Store St,London Rd(1828)and Whitehall Mills,nr, Derbys

org.note: Possibly at Primrose Valley Mill and Greenhouse Mill. near 'chapel en le firth'.
Also in Manchester. Possibly the same as or related to J Ibbotson at Hathergage & Hayfield
A `cripple' in 1824. Probably bro Joseph & Matthew Ibbotson. Bkpt: `London Gazette' 29/11/1844
Rebuilt mill with partner Littlewood. Part diss & Ibbotson sole occupier. Father of Denis,John,Henry & Wm
Imprisoned for debt 1820. Probably bro John & Joseph Ibbotson. Bankrupt 1844
Tenants of Duke of Norfolk Estate. Uncles of Charles Marsden
Also Ibotson. Part William East diss 1814 (by death)

address.addrLine: Res: Outseats Parish, nr Hathersage. Workplace: Bamford

org.note: Possibly associated with Green's House Mill, Outseats
Son of Joseph; bro Denis, John & Henry Ibbotson. Assoc S Brownell. Later at Storrs Paper Mill
Tenant J Smelter, Richmond. old interest in Green's House Mill to Dennis Ibbotson in 1801. Paid excise duties at Sheffield Collection in 1816
Aged 75 in 1831 described as `old & infirm & chargeable to Ecclesfield'. Illiterate (signed by mark)
Successors to Joseph Ibotoson. Tenants of Wilkinson of Chesterfield. Part diss c1787
Mill tenant. Paid excise duties at Sheffield Collection in 1816. Succeeeded by Matthew Ibotson (1840-5); Matthew & John Ibbotson (1846); John Gladwin (1847-50)
Successors to Mr Mercer & Co. Part Richard Ibotson (sic, deceased) & William East diss 1814
Part Dennis & Robert Ibbotson with William Mitchell diss: `London Gazette' 6/5/1828
Will dated 6/6/1675 proved at York Vol 56/249

address.addrLine: Near St George's Church, Southwark, Old Bailey (1742)

org.note: Son of Jane & Thomas Ilive/Iliff; bro Jacob & Isaac. Master to J.H.Hubbard
Apprenticed to Jos Nutting 1716. son Thomas Ilive, cit & ST

address.addrLine: Aldersgate St, o/a Aldersgate Coffee Hse (1730). London Hse, Aldersgate (1746)

org.bibl: GEN. The correspondence of Francis Blomefield (1705-1752), ed. David Stoker, (1992).
org.note: Also at Maidstone. Successor to parents Jane & Thomas Ilive/Iliff; bro Isaac & Abraham Ilive. Correspondence with Francis Blomefield, 1737. Sold typefoundry to John James 1740.

address.addrLine: At the printing office, at the Bible in East Lane nr the Fish Cross

org.note: Daughter of Eleanor & Thomas James. Widow & successor to Thomas Ilive. Mo & succeeded by Jacob. Mo Isaac & Abraham. Printer for StatCo
See various members of the ILIVE family (including JANE, ISAAC and THOMAS)
Also Ilyff; father of Isaac Ilive, Apprenticed to Jos Nutting 1716
Bound to Thomas Snowden 3.6.1678. Freed by Thomas Milbourne

address.addrLine: Under Searle's Gate, Lincoln's Inn, New Square

org.note: One press registered in 1842. Probably same as later Illingworth & Hicks.
Successors to R Nichols in August 1841
Engraved frontispiece for `Memoir of the Life of the late Henry Booker' (1814)

org.bibl: GEN. p. 4 Stokes, H.P., Cambridge Stationers Printers Bookbinders &c. (Cambridge: Bowes & Bowes, 1919)

org.note: Possibly same as/related to John Imison (same address).
Letter founder. Possibly same as/related to J Imison 1783-1795.
Possibly the same as John Imus
Amersham Franchise is in the Hundred of Burnham.
Probably the same as or related to James Imray of Budge Row
Probably the same as or related to James Imray of Featherstone St

address.addrLine: 2 Budge Row & 3 Old Fish St Hill

org.note: Possibly the same as John Imms

org.bibl: GEN. The Life of Thomas Gent – Part Two. http://www.eclipse.co.uk/exeshul/thomasgent/thomasgentparttwo.htm. 13.05.04
org.note: Free 1709. Probably Son of Randle Ince. First commercial printer in Chester. Succeeded by William Cooke
Publisher of the law journal reports.
Admitted to Chester Statco 1656. Probably Son of Peter Ince

address.addrLine: 31 Back of Shambles (1814-22). 34 Moot Hall (1818). 62 Briggate (1828-34)

org.note: Took over stock of late Isaac Nichols 1818. `Doubtful/consd good/Supposed Good, but doubtful' [O&B H/Ma]

address.addrLine: 31 Back of Shambles; house Queen's Square
St John's Court, St Martins-le-Grand. Cook's Court. Clarke's Place, Islington

org.note: Son of Joseph Indge of Wiltshire, labourer

address.addrLine: 2 St Johns Ct, St Martin le Grand (1778). 15 Clarks Pl, Islington (1786)

org.note: Son of Joseph Indge of Wiltshire, labourer. Apprenticed to William Oxlade. SFIP 403185 (1778) & 522116 (1786). LivSC 1780. Father of John Indge, Apprenticed to D Bye (1794a)
Son of John Indge, bookbiner. Apprenticed to Deodatus Bye. Part George Collier
Editons found in Hove reference library - uncertain whether this newspaper/magazine is local to Hove and/or the Sussex area.
Textwriter. Warden of Mistery of Textwriters (1439)
Married Rose Abbott of Polstead 23 spr 26/12/1687

address.addrLine: Near Turnpike, Mile End. 114 Whitechapel Rd (1805). 124 Whitechapel Rd

org.note: Imp: W E Gladstone (ed) Eton Miscellany by B Bouverie (1827)
Sold J Dolby's `Six Views of Eton College' [1838]

org.bibl: TS. Sheffield General Cemetery Burial records

org.note: See Hughes, Barnes & Ingham, Chapel en le Frith
Will dated 11/1/1669 proved at York Vol 50/447

address.addrLine: Pepper Lane; house Woodhouse Hill, Hunslett
Pepper Lane; house Woodhouse Hill, Hunslet

org.note: Master of Roger Graling until c1663 when Ingland left Godalming and Graling transferred his apprenticeship to William Hunt

Part Thomas Smith. John Hulme, apprentice, absconded from Smith & Ingle in 1788. With part insured mills & hse in tenure of Thomas Crompton in 1789 (SFIP 555670). Succeeeded by Thomas Smith & Ellin Ingle
Part Thomas Smith; trading as Smith & Ingle. Insured mills in 1797 & 1804 (SFIP 671522 & 765689). Probably cont trading as Smith & Ingle with same partners until 1829
With part Thomas Smith insured mill & hse in tenure of Thomas Crompton in 1783 (SFIP 481772). Succeeeded by Thomas Smith & Elizabeth Ingle c1788>
married at St Olave 1830. York Poll Book 1841
Probably same as Godfrey Ingman. Public Advertiser advert may be from 1760 rather than 1761.
See INMAN, Godfrey; Doncaster & possibly Sedbergh
Printed `Agricultural Press'. Succeeeded by widow, Mrs M Ingram
Printed & published `Nottingham Town & County Almanack for 1839'
Apprenticed to Roger Barnes. Admitted 1626. Bodleian binder. Father of William Ingram II
Son of William Ingram I. Possibly Bodleian binder
Possibly trading as J Boosey, Ingrey & Madeley
See C Ingrey, G E Madeley
See Thomas Martin, Charles Yates, John Emmet(t), Emmanuel Emmet, John Emmet jr, Joseph Emmett
Published Cruden's pamphlet `Mr Cruden Greatly Injured' (1739); evidently pseudonym
Involved in 'Bradford Courier' - possibly as proprietor or publisher. Possibly same as Thomas Inkersley.

address.addrLine: Bank St (1822). Bridge St (103 & Co in 1828). 26 Kirkgate (1834)

org.note: Possibly also Sedbergh. Aka Ingman. Possibly the same as INNMAN, Godfrey.
Apprenticed to Robert Holden aged 9 yrs 6 mths until aged 21 yrs; to be assigned clothing

address.addrLine: Back Turner St, (1816); 3 Back Turner St (1822); 14 Back Turner St (1824-28)

org.note: Printed 'the Family Instructor, of Fountain of Useful Knowledge' (1833)

address.addrLine: Wells St, Oxford St. 61 Wells St (1839&46)

org.note: Successor to William Innes jr. Trading as M S Innes & Co (1819-22). Succeeeded by Innes & Co (1823-8)

address.addrLine: 93 Gracechurch St. 1 Gracechurch St. 6 Lime Street Sq. 41 Lombard St. Blackraven St, Seething La &c

org.note: Registered press 1800. SFIP 424324 (1779/80) & 426070 (1780). Trading as William Innes 1784-1818; William Innes jr 1802-5; M S Innes & Co 1819-22; Innes & Co 1823-8. Probably conflates two men
Possibly the same as William Innes PR, Canterbury 1839
Successors to William Innes jr. Succeeeded by Innes & Co (1823-8)
Successors to M S Innes & Co (1819-22)
Possibly also Sedbergh 1737-8. Possibly the same as INMAN, Godfrey.

address.addrLine: 56 Campo La (1830) / 54 Campo La (1834) (7 in 1841 & 48) / Coopers Ct, High St (1839)

org.bibl: TS. Sheffield General Cemetery burial register
org.note: Depot for Tract Society. Printed pamphlet 1848. Died 29.5.1867.
Married as a widower Mary Allen widow 29/7/1665
With J Senex, W Taylor & J Osborn

address.addrLine: At the Prince's Arms, St Paul's Chyd

org.note: Aka Innes. Part bro William, trading as W & J Innys

address.addrLine: At the Prince's Arms, West end of St Paul's Chyd
Prince's Arms, West End St Paul's Chyd. Cr Ludgate St. 26 Paternoster Row (1744-56), End of St Paul's

org.note: Also Innes. His younger bro John (apprenticed 1710) subsequently a partner. Part J Richardson. StatCo. MSC (1747-8)
master of John Clarke 1713. master of James Hutton 1731
editions found in Hove reference library - uncertain whether this magazine is local to Hove and/or the Sussex area.
Advertisment Oct 1820 for sale for creditors of stock-in-trade

address.addrLine: Near Holbourne Conduit at the Sign of the Gunne

org.bibl: GEN. Bowers, Fredson, 'Was There a lost 1593 Edition of Marlowe's Edward II?', in 'Studies in Bibliography 25' (1972), pp143-148

org.note: two mills. J C Warren owned mill in 1907; mill burnt down 1930. See J Mills, John Bigg, S Bigg, J Billinghurst, John Bigg, Miles Rowe, Bigg & Rowe, William Challen, Rd Smith, William Devaynes, Thomas Harrison, B Pewtress

address.addrLine: 2 Green Arbour court, Old Bailey (London office)

org.note: First printed at both Ipswich by Stephen Piper, & Colchester by John Bawtree Harvey; later merged as `Ipswich Express & Essex & Suffolk Mercury' (1864). See Chas Sulley. Later `East Anglian Daily Times'

org.orgName: IPSWICH FRENCH LIBRARY AND NEWS ROOM

org.note: Successor to `Ipswich Journal' (1720-31). Had running title `Bagnall's News'. Ceased publication 1737. See John Bagnall and Bagnall's News

Title resurrected by William Craighton 1739. See also E Craighton, W Jackson, J Shave, S Jackson, P Jackson, R Taylor, & H Knights. Bot by `East Anglian Daily Times' 1902; ceased publication 1907. Proprietor in 1830: Postle Jackson.
Saturday (1828-37). Title resurrected by William Craighton 1739. See John Bagnall and Bagnall's News
130 subscribers & 2000 books in 1817. Librarian: Frederick Pawsey 1844

address.addrLine: S H Cowell's Room, Butter Mkt (1824)
S H Cowell's Room, Butter Mkt (1824)
Cross Key St, nr the Great White Horse Corner

org.note: Printed by Thomas Norris. Single issue 22/2/1735

org.orgName: (IPSWICH) BOOK CLUB AT THE GOLDEN LION

org.note: Possibly successor to E M & C Ireland (1826). John Ireland decorative/heraldic painter at same address 1845
Master of S Adams. Presumed widow of George (see Adams).
Widow of George Ireland I. Advertisment for Mrs Wyles's toothache cure [DDM23/2/1792]
Widow and successor to John Ireland.
Possibly succeeded by Ann Ireland. See also Elizabeth & Mary Ireland
Possibly the same as Francis Ireland
Possibly the same as F Ireland

address.addrLine: In the Market Place & Gallow Tree Gate

org.note: Apprenticed to John Ireland, free 8/8/1773. SFIP 383056 (1777). Probably succeeded by Ann Ireland; father of George Ireland II. Master of Samuel Adams
Apprenticed to John Ireland. Master of S Adams.
Only son of George Ireland I & Ann, free 13/8/1795. Master of John Fowler. Mayor 1821
Eldest and only son of George deceased. Son of Ann. Master of Fowler, Stanhope. Mayor 1821. Christened 25 July 1773, died 31 December 1826?
Son of Jos. (woolcomber) (JI's nephew?). Apprenticed to John Ireland.

address.addrLine: Ship Yd, Briggate (1834) / Rockingham St (1834) / 8 Little Templars St (1837)
Yard 71, Briggate; house 21 St James's Street

org.note: Printed `Chronicle'. Master of George Ireland I, Rowland Hurst. [See also LEI-CRO doc 5D43]
Son of George (woolcomber). Apprenticed to John Ireland (?). Master of George I; Hurst. Printer of Chronicle.
Probably same as other John Ireland's. Died 17/4/1810 age 63. Succeeeded by widow, Anne.
Probably the same as John Ireland

address.addrLine: Res: Parish of Gt St Mary's

org.note: Only surviving imprint was probably sold in J Cawood's hse: s/o Holy Ghost in Paul's Chyd
Began life as weaver in Spitalfields. Became PS and taught himself engraving. Father of William Henry Ireland, literary forger (1771-1835)
Literary forger. Son of Samuel Ireland
Also known as the `Sheffield Advertiser'. See James Montgomery

address.addrLine: 3 princess street; home- cornbrook place , hulme

org.note: Sworn in as a constable for Bury 3/11/1808
Sold pamphlet printed by J Crome of Sheffield 1822

address.addrLine: Shaddongate (1821). Globe La, Scotch St (1821-2). Theatre La (1828-34)

org.note: Registered press 17/10/1821 & 26/7/1824. Imprints 1825-31. Published The Citizen or Literary & Scientific Mirror' (fortnightly)

address.addrLine: 39 Oldham St. (1846), Nicholas Croft, High St (1855). 5 Princess St (1865)

org.note: Sold William Sturgeon's `Course of Twelve Elementary Lectures on Galvanism' (1843). Ptd/published Quaker anti-slavery tracts
Exchanged apprentices with C Barker & E White sr. Assignee of R Day. Assoc Thomas Butter (1581). Freed as Draper 1573
Also as John R Isaac & Co (1829)
Part Isaac Angel Isaacs & Mary Ann Davies

address.addrLine: 211 Edgware Rd. 1 Parker St, Westminster (1838). 18 Sherborne Lane, City (c1840&46)
Res: Parish of St Giles, Cripplegate (1608>)

org.note: 1st wife was Elizabeth Roberts probably daughter of his master, James Roberts
Apprenticed to Benjamin Motte 1718. son Thomas, cit & ST
son Thomas, apprenticed to Benjamin Motte 1718
Employed by John Hayes, 1676. Cambridge Will.
Marked on O.S. Two Inch Drawing No. 93 (1789, date of survey). See Joseph Molineux, Thomas Johnston, Arthur Lee, Messrs Molineux & Johnson
Mill for sale in 1756. See William Smith, Ann Geery, Ed Smith, Thomas Wood, Mrs Smith

org.bibl: MYERS/HARRIS. Michael Turner 'The Personnel of the Stationers' Company 1800-30: Work in Progress' 78-101

org.note: Secretaries: Rev Edmund Kell & John James Foquett.

Apprenticed to Hugh Jackson, stationer. In 1594 acquired printing material of John Wolfe later passed to R Hearne. With Joice Norton & Richard Whitakers. On a committee appointed by the Stationers' company to reduce the number of master printers to 14 (1604).
Dead when son Adam apprenticed James Cotterell 1653
Registered press 2/11/1829. Imprint 1834-5,. Circulating library up to 1900.

address.addrLine: Golden Anchor against St Dunstan's Church in Fleet St

org.note: Also Isteed. StatCo. Possibly related to John Isted

address.addrLine: Golden Ball against St Dunstan's Church in Fleet St

org.note: Probably the same as Madam Isted who gave 10s to Bowyer after his fire. Advertised bks in 1711 & 1725

address.addrLine: Nr Itton Court, Itton parish, nr Chepstow

org.note: One of six mills in the neighbourhood of `Eton Court' (sic). Other mills include Little Mill, Itton Mill, Dyer's Mill, Pandy Mills & Mounton Mill. See John Reece
See Itton Court Mill. See William Fry, James Ablart, Samuel Jenkins sr, William Jones, Samuel Jenkins jr, Jones & Co
Son of Ed & Susan (nee Mingay). Apprenticed to James Wright (wage 3s (1844) 8s (1851) per wk). Married Ellen Selina
Antiquary. Amateur printer, introduced printing to Yarmouth 1772
Premises described as sale shop in 1785
Married Anne Tomlinson of same a widow aged 28 on 1/12/1754
Published John R D Colston's `Report of Forensic Meetings, 1848' (1849)
Possibly the same as Stowford Mill. See William Pym

address.addrLine: On the boundary of the parishes of Maidstone & Loose

org.note: See R Burnham, J How, T Mantiloe, T Pine, A Pine, T Gilford, S Pine, E Pine, R Worsley, J Pine, J Martin, R Woollett, N Moore, R Edmeads, E Jupp, W Hearnden, T Smith, H Allnutt

address.addrLine: 4 Turnagain La, Farringdon St. 8 Turnagain St &2&3 Wheatsheaf Yard, Farringdon st (1846)

org.note: Metal-furniture founder, printers ball & roller mfr
Brass rule cutters, space line & metal furniture founders.
Turner in ordinary to the Queen
Manufacturer of japan & enamel leathers, tablecovers etc.
